The people of this province — they need me, Nyssa. If I am destined to meet my end in their service — well, then, I shall face my fate smiling. I still have my spells, remember.
But will your magic be enough?

FX: THWUMP AS MAGIC CARPET UNFURLS ITSELF
(JUMPING ONTO CARPET) Carpet, hear me! Fly, Carpet! Fly!
(FX: WHOOSH OF CARPET TAKING OFF. MUSIC RISES... THEN HARSH CUT

SCENE 2: INT. THRONE ROOM
NB: WE ARE BACK TO NATURALISM NOW
(FX: EXOTIC SULTAN’S THRONE ROOM. THE SLIGHT TINKLE OF
WINDCHIMES, PLUSH SILK CUSHIONS, MARBLE FLOORS)
(SILKY) And what happened next, girl?
(UNSURE) Well, I — I knew I had to get to the Doctor, your highness.
So you flew over the ravine.
Yes, sort of.
On your magic carpet.
It’s not exactly a magic carpet, but [close enough] —
Just like a little bird...
(FX: LOW SNICKERING OF SURROUNDING GUARDS & HANDMAIDENS
If I hadn’t, you see, the rock monster would... well, it would have [killed the Doctor]
(HARSH) Enough!
FX: HE CLAPS HIS HANDS. EVERYONE FALLS SUDDENLY SILENT
It seems we have a hero in our dungeons. A slayer of demons, like in the tales we heard at our grandmother’s knee. He rides a flying carpet and he knows no fear. Yes?
Please, honoured Sultan, I was just trying to explain in words you’d understand...
You think me stupid?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 6
No!
Ah. Then you intended to deceive me?
No! I told you — my only purpose in coming here was to ask for you to release the Doctor.
Yes, this ‘Doctor’. A common thief.
He’s no thief. He was just searching for something. If he doesn’t find it soon — well, we’1ll all be in terrible danger!
This man broke into my palace. Not to steal, you say, but to stop ‘demons’ from coming here.
Demons, yes!
(ASIDE) Have my guards seen any demons? Nazar?
FX: MORE LOW SNICKERS
No, your magnificence.
(TO NYSSA) Then, girl, this story of yours is the only evidence you can give me that your Doctor is a demon-slayer.
I suppose.
From another world.
FX: GIGGLING BREAKS OUT AMONGST THE COURT
Your highness...
A world where carpets fly?
FX: LOUDER LAUGHTER THROUGH:
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 7
I’m sorry, honoured Sultan. I didn’t mean to insult your intelligence —
FX: SULTAN CLAPS HIS HANDS. LAUGHTER STOPS
This city did not become great because its Sultan is ignorant. This may be how you convinced my guards to let you pass, but you should have thought better than to try to fool me.
Your excellency, my apologies. The guards thought her stories would amuse you.
If I wanted amusement, I would have asked her to dance. (THE
) You don’t dance, do you, girl?
No.
(SADLY) No. (BEAT) Take her away, Nazar. Then call for the executioner. It’s time we cut this thieving ‘Doctor’ down to Size.
As you command, O Wise Sultan.
(SEIZED BY GUARDS) Executioner?! No, you can’t!
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 3: INT. DUNGEON — CELL
(FX: FADE UP. FROM THE FAR SIDE OF A STONE WALL — I.E. THE
CELL — WE HEAR THE MUFFLED GRUNTS OF THE DOCTOR
AGAINST A HEAVY STONE BLOCK, WHICH SCRAPES AGAINST STONE. EFFORT, SCRAPE; EFFORT, SCRAPE; EFFORT... THEN STONE
THROUGH HOLE, HITTING THE FLOOR ON OUR SIDE)
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Ha! Stone walls do not a prison make! Now... looks big enough, I should be able to just (SQUEEZING THROUGH HOLE IN WALL) squeeze through...
FX: TUMBLES THROUGH HOLE
Ah. (GETTING UP) Not quite what I’d hoped for.
(SLIGHTLY OFF) And what is the meaning of this intrusion?
(STARTLED) Oh! Terribly sorry, didn’t see you in the dark. (WALKING FORWARD) Hello, I’m the [Doctor. ]
If you’re here to kill me, I warn you — I have a dozen guards outside! (STARTS TO CALL) [Guards-! ]
Please, don’t! I was just trying to liberate myself by breaking through the wall of my cell. Only I seem to have ended up in yours.
(SHOCKED) You came from the dungeons?
Rather poorly designed dungeons, unfortunately. This should be
a corridor. I’m good with corridors.
You’re a criminal?!
FX: HE RUSHES TO DOOR, BATTERS AGAINST HEAVY WOOD THROUGH:
Guards! Help! There’s a criminal, here in my room! Help!!!
Please, there’s really no need to raise the alarm —
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 9
Help! Help!!!
FX: FROM BEHIND DOOR, JAILER’S HEAVY FOOTSTEPS APPROACHING
Tell you what, why don’t I just slip back the way I came —
Hurry! A criminal! (FADING WITH EFFORT) In here...!
FX: FROM BEHIND DOOR, FOOTSTEPS STOP. A GRILLE SLIDES OPEN.
(THROUGH GRILLE, SARCASTIC) Of course there’s a criminal in your room, ‘your highness’. That’s why this door’s locked. Now keep it down!
FX: THE GRILLE IS SLID SHUT HARSHLY. FOOTSTEPS LEAVING, OFF
COUGHING, ILL) But — but you can’t! (COUGHING
(RUSHING TO HELP) You’re not well. Here, let me help you.
So disrespectful...
You need to lie down. Come on: over to the bed.
(FX: SCUFFLE OF FOOTSTEPS AS DOCTOR HELPS SETTLE OLD MAN ON
Thank you. A curious world, is it not, when criminals are kinder than those supposed to protect one from criminals?
I’m not a criminal, I’m the Doctor.
(WEAK) A doctor? Yes, I asked for a doctor. I get so tired these days...
Just try to rest. You’1ll be alright.
(WEAK) The Sultan never rests.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 10
(GETS UP TO FEEL THE WALLS) A corner cell, that was my mistake. The corridor’s behind this wall, I think. (FX:
) What was that about the Sultan?
Getting old. So very, very old.
Older but not wiser. (FX: MORE TAPPING ON STONE) He wouldn’t listen to a word I said: just blocked his ears and had me thrown me in here.
Perhaps, Doctor, you should explain to him how you came to be here, and he might look more kindly on your intrusion?
(FX: STILL TAPPING) Anyone who condemns a sick man like you to this sort of squalor can’t be reasoned with. (STOPS TAPPING) I only hope Nyssa isn’t foolish enough to try.

Squalor? There isn’t a chamber to equal this in the whole Arabian Peninsula. They say that that inveterate sybarite, the Caliph, has installed spies in the palace purely to send back secret drawings of this chamber for the Caliph’s architects to
copy.
Well at least you’ve not lost your sense of humour.

(IGNORING THIS) I can well believe it, too. See the lining on the walls? Gold leaf, with a turquoise inlay, to catch the glimmer of the sun. The window you climbed through, Doctor, is almost as pretty as the view, don’t you think?
Window-? You mean the hole I made in the wall?
You're a physician, you say? Forgive me if I seemed a little confused when you arrived. My guards — they should have announced you.
(REALIZING HE’S MAD) Ah. You think you’re the Sultan, don’t you?
Why — yes, Doctor. Who else would I be?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 4: INT. THRONE ROOM
FX: NYSSA IS HELD BY GUARDS
(STRUGGLING) Please, Sultan — I’m telling the truth!
Take her away, Nazar, lest her madness be infectious.
Of course, your majesty. (TO GUARD) Guards: remove the female.
(STRUGGLING) You say you’re not ignorant, your highness. Well I say you are — and wilfully so, for you choose not to listen!
FX: INTAKES OF BREATH FROM GUARDS & HANDMAIDENS
There are other worlds, and we travel between them!
Noble Sultan, let me slay her on the spot! (FX: DRAWING HIS SWORD) Her blood shall water the roses in the palace garden.
No. Wait. Guards — out. You handmaidens, too. I would speak more with this creature.
FX: THE GUARDS & HANDMAIDENS BEGIN TO LEAVE
You too, Nazar. Leave me your sword for protection.
Surely your excellency cannot believe her lies?
Don’t tell me what I can and cannot do, Nazar. Now: out!
(HANDING OVER HIS SWORD & OBEYING) Your majesty.
FX: NAZAR FOLLOWS THE OTHERS. HEAVY DOOR SHUTTING
Why did you send them away?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 12

What? Let them stay and have the secrets of the stars overheard by illiterate guards and fawning girls? No. Now, relieve me of my ignorance or I shall use Nazar’s sword to relieve you of your pretty head. You have been to other worlds, you say?
Yes.
And these demons you claim are coming here — they are from other worlds too?

There’s a beacon — a device which transmits a signal, like a mirror flashing from a mountain top — hidden somewhere in this building. It belongs to a species called the Gantha. They were paid to come to this world and find something of great value. Whatever it was, they found it here, in your palace — and they activated their beacon the moment they discovered it.
Then these ‘Gantha’ are the demons of which you speak?
No. They’re just muscle for hire: intergalactic thugs. They found whatever it was and cleared out. Their beacon is summoning whoever hired them, so they might retrieve it. Those are the ‘demons’.
I see. So which of my treasures are they coming for?
(FRUSTRATED) That’s what the Doctor was trying to find out! We don’t know what it is, or who is coming.
I understand now why you made up a story about flying carpets.
The Gantha only work for the worst kind of monsters. We need to find and deactivate that beacon — then you and your palace will be out of danger. Please, your highness: this isn’t a fairytale.
(BEAT) Very well. I believe you.
Then you’1ll release the Doctor?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 13
No. Not yet.
Why not?

This ‘beacon’ can wait. Demons may ride on the wings of night, but I doubt even they could cross the stars in a mere matter of hours. We have time. Besides, I want to hear more about these other worlds. About you... and your ‘Doctor’.
We can tell you afterwards. Both of us!
I'd prefer to be told now — and by you.
Why?
My guards were right: I do want amusement. You have heard of Shaharazad, who spent one thousand and one nights telling stories to her Sultan to save the life of another?
A thousand and one nights-?!
I doubt I will keep you as long as that.
This is preposterous!

Preposterous or not, it’s the only way to save your precious Doctor. I shall stay his execution just so long as you keep me amused. And who knows? If I like your stories enough, I may even release the fellow.
And if you don’t?
Then the Doctor dies and you take his place in the dungeons.
The Doctor says you can tell a lot about a man by the way he treats his prisoners.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 14
It seems to me that a man like the Doctor can be no stranger to a prison cell.
That’s true enough. There was this one world we visited, not long ago — (CUTTING HERSELF SHORT) No, I’m not playing your
stupid game.
Come, Nyssa. Just one story, then I’1l release the Doctor and we can find this beacon of yours. I promise.
How can I trust you?
You can’t afford not to. Now, tell me about this other world. Why did you go there?

We didn’t mean to. The TARDIS — our ship — it just took us there by accident. (FX: BEGIN CROSSFADE TO NEXT SCENE:) I'd never seen anywhere so desolate. It wasn’t even a real world; just an asteroid in the middle of space, as far as it could be from life or warmth or hope...
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 15
1: MY BROTHER’S KEEPER
SCENE 5: EXT. ALIEN PLANET — PRISON YARD
FX: BLEAK, WINDSWEPT ATMOS. TARDIS MATERIALISES, DOOR OPENS
(FROM WITHIN THE TARDIS) You’re quite sure this outfit isn’t a little too showy? (EMERGES FROM THE TARDIS. ABRUPT REALISATION) Oh.
(FROM WITHIN) Nothing’s too showy for the grand coronation of the High Hierophant of the Five Revealed Truths! (EMERGES FROM THE TARDIS. ABRUPT REALISATION) Oh.
We’re not at the Celestial Basilica, are we?
Apparently not.
Then where are we?
I’m not sure. A remote outpost, maybe? Or some kind of fortress. Not exactly bustling with life.
Lt Sa. prison,- 1sn*t 2?
I admit, the fifty-foot-high perimeter wall does tend to give that impression.
I had enough of prisons on Folly. Can we go?
(FAINT, ECHOING FROM DISTANCE) Help! Please help me!
Did you hear that?
(WARNINGLY — THIS ISN’T THEIR PROBLEM) Doctor... The coronation of the High Hierophant, remember? Perfumed rain falling from clouds sown with powdered diamonds — you wouldn’t want to miss that.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 16
I’ve had the invitation for the last three hundred years, Nyssa.
(FAINT, ECHOING FROM DISTANCE) He wants to kill me-! Please!
I can wait a little longer. (FX: HE CLOSES THE TARDIS DOOR)
Come on!
FX: THEY EXIT HURRIEDLY.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 6: INT. PRISON — CORRIDOR/EXECUTION CHAMBER
(FX: MUFFLED ANGRY ENERGY CRACKLE FROM BEHIND A CLOSED DOOR.
& NYSSA’S HURRIED FOOTSTEPS RUN UP.)
(FROM WITHIN; TORTURED) It burns..! Make it stop!
(LOUDLY) It’s alright, we’re here! (TO THE DOCTOR) Doctor, the door -
(FRANTICALLY PRESSING BUTTONS) A logarithmic key combination. This might take a little time —
FX: ANOTHER ENERGY CRACKLE
SCREAMS FROM WITHIN
(TRIUMPHANTLY) Aha! (A RUDE ‘ERROR’ BLEEP) Ah.
Here, let me try. You never were any good with logarithms.
FX: NYSSA BEGINS PRESSING KEYS ON THE DOOR LOCK PAD
I’1ll have you know I was first [in my class] -
FX: CONFIRMATION BLEEP FROM PAD
Oh.
FX: CLANG OF HEAVY METAL DOOR OPENING
(IN PAIN) At last. Please... make it [stop!] (FX: ENERGY
CRACKLE) (GASPS)
(RUSHING IN) What is this thing?
An electric chair. High voltage passes through the conducting plates and electrocutes the occupant.
Why would anyone make such a thing?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 18
(GRITTED TEETH) To torture me, of course — (FX: ENERGY CRACKLE) (GASPS)

How lucky you were, Nyssa, to grow up in the civilized serenity of the Traken Union. (STEPPING FORWARD) But there’s a whole universe of horrors beyond — (WALKS INTO FORCEFIELD) (FX: SHIMMERING HUM AS HE DOES SO. IN PAIN) Ow!
A force field?
Surrounding the inner chamber.
FX: CRACKLE
(IN PAIN) Please! He’s going to kill me!
There must be something we can do!
(FX: HUM INCREASES AS HE PUSHES AGAINST FIELD, DECREASES AS HE RELAXES. IT HURTS TO DO SO) Interesting. You see the positrons rushing to resist my hand when I push against it?
Doesn’t that hurt?
Yes. You try it.
It’s all right: I believe you.
Just do it. Please.
(EFFORT. HUM INCREASES. IN PAIN) You’re right: it does hurt.
Keep pushing — hard as you can. See? The positrons are swarming to resist you now.
(EFFORT. IN PAIN) I take it there’s a reason I’m doing this.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 19

It’s a fixed-atom force field, designed to repel entry at a Single point only. Your pushing there creates a weaker point elsewhere in the field. (BEGINS PUSHING AT ANOTHER SPOT. IN PAIN, PUSHING THROUGH THE FORCEFIELD LIKE PASSING THROUGH JELLY) Weak enough... for me... to squeeze through...
FX: SMALL ANGRY HUM AS HE DOES SO
Done it!
(STILL PUSHING. IN PAIN) Can I stop now?
Sorry — yes.
FX: AS NYSSA RELAXES, HUM RECEDES
Good. Give me a moment to recover — then I’11 let you both out.
You can’t, I’m afraid. The trick only works if both parties are on the same side of the force field.
FX: A SPARK OF THE ELECTRIC CHAIR
YELLS OUT
And this fellow would never survive the process.
So you’re stuck inside the force field?
Temporarily. Which is why I need you to find out where it’s being powered from, and shut it down. I’1ll see if I can undo these restraints while you’re gone.
(PAIN. PANTING. EXHAUSTED) There’s a control room, below ground. Two floors down, red door — (FX: CRACKLE) (CRIES OUT)
I’ll find it. (EXITING) I’1l be back as soon as I can, Doctor!
(IN PAIN) Quick, before he comes back!
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 20
(UNDOING RESTRAINTS) Just hold still, I need to time releasing the manacles in between successive [shocks—]
FX: CRACKLE
DOCTOR/PRISONER:
CRY OUT, SHOCKED SIMULTANEOUSLY
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 7: INT. PRISON — CORRIDOR
FX: NYSSA HURRYING DOWN METAL STEPS
(ONTO LOWER LEVEL) Level Minus Two. Now... red door, red door... I think I’1ll try down [here]- (SUDDENLY GRABBED) Aah!
(BEHIND HER, HOLDING ON) Who are you? What are you doing here?
(STRUGGLING) Let me go and I’1l tell you!
Oh, you’ll tell me alright. (FX: PRODUCES JANGLING SHACKLE) Head still, if you don’t want the collar to choke you —
(STRUGGLING) What are you doing?
I said, head still!
FX: SNAP OF COLLAR ROUND NYSSA’S NECK, ENERGY HUM
(RELEASING NYSSA) There, that’s better.
(GASPING) Get this — thing off me!
Careful. It doesn’t do to tamper with a compliance collar.
A what?
A compliance collar. It ensures you tell the truth.
(DISMISSIVE) And how exactly does it do that?
By passing 10,000 volts through your brain, should it detect a lie. Now: who you are, and what you’re doing here.
My name’s Nyssa. I just arrived here, with my friend the Doctor —
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 22
And where is this Doctor?
Upstairs.
With the prisoner?
The man you’re torturing, yes. We’re trying to free him.
You what?
He’s in agony — screaming for his life! What you’re doing is inhuman!
You stupid [idiots]- (CUTS HIMSELF OFF). Have you any idea of what you’ve done? Come on! (GRABS HER)
Where are we going?
To the control room. There’s a communicator in there.
You're wasting your time. You’ll never talk the Doctor into condoning torture.
(HURRYING, DRAGGING HER) It’s not him I want to talk to. If this Doctor friend of yours is in the cell with that thing, he’s already as good as dead.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 8: INT. PRISON — EXECUTION CHAMBER
(FX: FORCE FIELD ENERGY HUM. CHAINS AND RESTRAINTS FALLING TO FLOOR)
There. Not bad for a man with singed fingers. Must remember to thank dear old Harry Houdini for the lock-picking tips. Can you stand?
(GETTING UP) I... I think so. We have to get out of here before...
Before ‘he’ comes back, I know. Don’t worry, Nyssa’1l soon have that force field turned off. I’m the Doctor, by the way.
FX: CRACKLE OF INTERCOM CHANNEL OPENING
(ON INTERCOM) Doctor? Can you hear me?
Nyssa! What’s happening with the force field?
(ON INTERCOM) Doctor, there’s someone else here —
It’s him! I told you!
(ON INTERCOM) Doctor, this is the warden speaking. The prisoner you’re with is a dangerous criminal.
Don’t listen to him!
Dangerous or not, nothing this man has done can justify such barbaric treatment!
(ON INTERCOM) Ask him, Doctor. Ask that creature what he did. (CHUCKLE) But be quick about it — you don’t have much time.
FX: OMINOUS CHIME.
Oh no, no!
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 24
(ON INTERCOM) What’s that noise?
(ON INTERCOM) The execution protocol has been activated. The clock is ticking, creature.
Execution?!
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 9: INT. PRISON — CONTROL ROOM
FX: GENTLE HUM OF SOPHISTICATED ELECTRONIC MACHINERY
(OVER THE INTERCOM) Warden this is madness. I demand [to see]
FX: WITH A FLICK THE WARDEN SWITCHES OFF THE INTERCOM
Best not to hear what’s about to happen.
What do you mean ‘Execution Protocol’?
It’s an automated failsafe, designed for security breaches
such as this. The force field surrounding that creature has begun to contract. In less than six minutes’ time, it’ll be smaller than he is. He’ll be crushed to death.
But the Doctor’s in there!
(THOUGHTFUL) You’re right: that does make a difference.
You’re going to let him go?
No, I was just pondering the physics: the added mass means death will come sooner. (FX: PRESSING BUTTONS) In four minutes, fifty-six seconds, to be precise.
But the Doctor hasn’t done anything! You’re murdering an innocent man!
Innocent? He tried to free a highly dangerous criminal. He interfered with due process.
You can’t just execute him!
I’ve no choice! You know as well as I do that we can’t risk that creature getting out!
Why? Who is he? What’s he done?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 26
(AMAZED) You really don’t know who the prisoner is, do you?
No, I really don’t know who the prisoner is — and neither does the Doctor!
Remarkable! The compliance collar hasn’t shocked you. (LAUGHS) You’re telling the truth!
I find precious little to laugh at. So tell me: who is this dangerous villain?
It’s the Miaxa. Yes, girl, your friend’s locked in there with one of the wickedest monsters in creation. Now do you see what you’ve done?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 10: INT. PRISON — EXECUTION CHAMBER
(FX: BUZZ/HUM OF FORCEFIELD BECOMES GRADUALLY CLOSER
SUBSEQUENT EXECUTION CHAMBER SCENES)

(A BUZZ AS THE DOCTOR BURNS HIS HAND ON THE FORCE FIELD.) Ow! That forcefield’s getting closer. (LOUDLY) Hello? Look, if I’m to be crushed to my constituent atoms along with this man, can I at least ask why?
He won’t answer. He never does.
Maybe someone else will. There must be other people here: guards.
No-one. Only him. And me.
That’s all? A prison at the edge of nowhere, with only one prisoner and one jailer? (THE THOUGHT OCCURS TO HIM) How long have you been here?
I.. I don’t know. He won’t tell me. He just keeps on tormenting me. Torturing me. Telling me to confess.
Confess? To what?
I don’t know! He never tells me. Oh, Doctor, if you only knew the things he’s done to me, time and time again! Over and over, until... (STARTS SOBBING) until I die.
Until what?

Don’t you see? This has happened before. I’ve died in this room, time and time again. And I don’t know why. He never tells me. Don’t you understand? He’s calls me a monster — but it’s he who’s the monster, not me.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 11: INT. PRISON — CONTROL ROOM
(FX: AS BEFORE. LITTLE BLEEPS AS THE WARDEN CHECKS THE
Three minutes nine seconds now.
Who is he, this Miaxa?
He created an empire. The Most Serene Blightstar Hegemony. An alliance such as the universe had never before witnessed. Ten thousand worlds united, in peace and prosperity.
Well, how’s that a crime?

He destroyed it — just like that. (CLICKS HIS FINGERS) Plunged it into war. Thousands of once-thriving planets are now just lifeless rock, orbiting dead stars. So many worlds, so many dead. The legacy of the Miaxa.
And it’s your job to make sure he pays?
I am the Warden. He is the prisoner. He must be made to confess. He must be punished for his crimes.
On whose authority? Who put you in charge here?
(DOUBTS CREEPING IN) I.. I am the Warden. I have always been in charge. You’re trying to confuse me. You and your Doctor, you’re working for him, aren’t you? He brought you here. To help him escape.
You know that’s not true.
FX: NYSSA STARTS PRESSING BUTTONS
What are you doing?
(STILL OPERATING) Pausing the countdown.
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 29
You can’t do that! You must comply!
Must I? (FINAL FLICK OF A SWITCH) There: countdown paused at one minute forty-eight seconds.
That collar... it must be faulty.
Look, I am innocent! The Doctor is innocent! So what makes you sure your prisoner’s not innocent, too?
The things he did. He has to remember them. He has to confess. He has to accept his share of the guilt.
What do you mean ‘his share of the guilt’?
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 12: INT. PRISON — EXECUTION CHAMBER
FX: BUZZ/HUM OF FORCEFIELD CLOSE, BUT NOT CONTRACTING
The force field: it’s stopped contracting!
He’s done that before — the Warden. He likes to draw it out.
Tell me: how is it you can remember being executed?
I— I don’t know...
Well, let’s start with what you do know: what’s your name?
I don’t know.
Very well. The Warden — what’s his name?
That I do know. He is called the Miaxa.
(WITH REALIZATION) The Miaxa? Oh, I’m so sorry. I’m so very sorry.
FX: THE INTERCOM SPRINGS TO LIFE
(ON INTERCOM) Doctor, can you hear me?
FX: CROSS TO
1,001 NIGHTS (FINAL) Page 31
